title: Rody ‘fear factor’ cuts firecracker injuries

organizations.name: provincial disaster risk reduction and management office
provincial risk reduction and management office

text:
Rody ‘fear factor’ cuts firecracker injuries (The Philippine Star)   Quezon City Police District director Chief Supt. Guillermo Eleazar presents to media at Camp Karingal illegal firecrackers confiscated in different areas in the city. BOY SANTOS 
MANILA, Philippines – A woman was burned to death in Bayawan, Negros Oriental while houses were gutted in separate fire incidents during the New Year’s Eve revelry, which recorded the lowest number of injuries in 10 years – a development attributed by the Department of Health (DOH) to fears that President Duterte would harshly punish revelers who celebrate with firecrackers. 
A two-year-old boy also perished in a fire in Quezon City yesterday, but authorities could not determine yet if the incident was related to the use of firecrackers or fireworks. 
Health Secretary Paulyn Ubial said 350 people were reported injured by firecrackers and fireworks this year compared to a 10-year average of 1,000. 
Even in Bulacan, the country’s firecrackers and fireworks capital, the Provincial Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Office reported a much lower number of victims compared to last year. 
“People are now afraid to light firecrackers because of the President,” Ubial said. “They have this impression that somehow they will get caught or they will be punished.” 
Duterte, 71, has drawn global criticism including from the United States and the United Nations for a war on drugs that has killed over 5,000 people.   
Duterte won last year’s elections in a landslide on a promise to eradicate narcotics by killing tens of thousands of criminals. 
He also vowed to roll out Davao-style law and order measures nationwide, including banning smoking in restaurants and hotels and curbing drinking in public places. 
Duterte last month said he would issue an order to ban people from using firecrackers, limiting their use to community fireworks displays like what he did in Davao City while he was still mayor. 
“The least that I can say or do is just to issue a warning that it’s very, very dangerous,” he said pending the order’s release. 
But despite the “remarkable” decline in injuries, Ubial said there was “still a lot of misery” as she echoed the President’s concern that children were falling victim to firecracker use and indiscriminate firing of guns. 
And as in past years, victims ranging from one year old to the elderly suffered injuries due to firecrackers and fireworks while causing fires in other areas. 
Personnel of the local Bureau of Fire and Protection (BFP) recovered the body of Arlene Pinanonang, 48, businesswoman, from the fire scene in Barangay Boyco, Bayawan, Negros Oriental. 
BFP investigation showed the incident occurred when firecrackers exploded and razed the victim’s store. Fifteen others were reported injured due to firecrackers in Negros Occidental. 
Fires also broke out in Barangay Mansilingan, Bacolod City and Sta. Ana, Manila due to firecrackers and fireworks. 
In general, fires during the New Year revelry went down by 17.24 percent this year, the BFP national headquarters said. 
The BFP reported that from Dec. 31 to yesterday, there were 48 fires compared to 58 recorded in the same period last year. 
In Bulacan, the Provincial Risk Reduction and Management Office (PDRRMO) said from 100 last year, only 38 people were admitted to the different district hospitals in Bulacan and at the Bulacan Medical Center due to injuries related to firecrackers and fireworks. 
Liz Mungcal, Bulacan PDRRMO executive officer, said the victims were aged 11 to 15 and the decline in the number of victims could be attributed to “Oplan Ingat Paputok 2017” of the provincial government. Young victims 
Ubial said a three-year-old child from Cabanatuan suffered a hand injury during the New Year’s Eve celebration and the worst case involved 15-year-old Emilyn Villanueva, who slipped into a coma after a stray bullet hit her head while watching a fireworks display in Malabon. 
“This is one of our saddest incidents,” Ubial said. 
Health officials in Bicol said 16 persons were injured in various areas in the region, six of them children aged one to six. From Dec. 21 to yesterday, 56 people were reported injured by firecrackers, a 43 percent decrease from last year’s 99. 
In Barangay Rosario, Cervantes, Ilocos Sur, 60-year-old Renato Palomo lost three fingers after a huge firecracker called “Goodbye De Lima” prematurely exploded in his hand. 
In Tarlac province, 17 persons were injured, eight in Bulacan and two in Pampanga, according to Chief Superintendent Aaron Aquino of Police Regional Office 3. 
At the Region 1 Medical Center in Dagupan City, 16 persons were brought for treatment of firecracker-related injuries, some of whom suffered amputations, due to the New Year merrymaking. The hospital also recorded six other victims from Dec. 24 to 31. 
Ten individuals were hurt by firecrackers in Cagayan Valley; 18 in Isabela and two each in Cagayan and Nueva Vizcaya. A hospital worker cleans a patient’s wound caused by a firecracker yesterday. JOVEN CAGANDE 
Superintendent Chivalier Iringan, Police Regional Office 2 information officer, said the victims, both minors and adults, were injured by the banned pla-pla, piccolo and pyrotechnics like kwitis and luces. 
Iringan also a reported a decrease in the number of firecracker victims this year. 
Davao City, where Duterte served as mayor for more than 20 years and whose daughter, Sara is current local chief executive, registered zero firecracker-related deaths or injuries along with Zamboanga City. 
It is the 14th year for Davao City to avoid any casualties and injuries from firecrackers, fireworks and stray bullets. In 2001, the President banned the sale of firecrackers and pyrotechnics as mayor of the city. 
Sara thanked the Dabawenyos for cooperating with the local government, noting that the city is proof that enjoyable and meaningful celebrations could be done without firecrackers and fireworks and only with the use of torotot (toy trumpets). 
The countdown to 2017, attended by around 5,000 Dabawenyos at Rizal Park in Davao City, was highlighted by competitions such as the Most Creative Torotot, Best Torotot-inspired Costume, Best Torotot-inspired Cosplay, Best Torotot-Hip Hop Dance Group, and Best Torotot-inspired Zumba Dancer. 
For her part, Zamboanga City Mayor Ma. Isabelle Climaco-Salazar said it was the city’s third year to experience zero-casualty after it imposed a total ban on the sale and use of firecrackers and any pyrotechnic devices. 
The city initially imposed the ban on firecrackers in 2013 following the deadly siege in this city that traumatized residents. 
After seeing the positive effects, the city government through the city council approved an ordinance implementing a total ban. – Ramon Efren Lazaro, Celso Amo, Raymund Catindig, Gilbert Bayoran, Rey Galupo, Emmanuel Tupas, Edith Regalado, Roel Pareño, Ric Sapnu, Cesar Ramirez, Victor Martin
